title: Zimbabwe: Supreme Court Ruling - Sino-Zim Firm Fires 400 Workers
text:
Zimbabwe: Black Opal Pageant Gets Bigger and Better 
"We were given letters of termination of our contracts at the close of the day yesterday," said one of the affected workers. 
"Permanent employees only have been thrown out. Surprisingly they just wrote us letters without any formal communication from management. 
"However, our workers' union has since advised us to withhold signing the papers." 
The move comes as labour unions have appealed to President Robert Mugabe to invoke his powers to stop the "madness" which has seen over 700 workers being fired within a week. 
Zimbabwe Textile Workers Union Secretary-General Silas Kuvheya said 247 of their members have been fired and would go home empty handed. 
"We are going to engage with the management at Sino-Zim to ensure that this is stopped. 
"The Supreme Court ruling has set a bad precedence and, definitely, more people will be affected," he said. 
Chief Justice Godfrey Chidyausiku, sitting with four other Judges of appeal, last week ruled that employers could terminate a contract of employment through three months' notice and not pay any benefit to the worker despite the number of years one would have worked for the firm. 
The ruling has seen a number of companies rushing through the dismissal of hundreds of workers this week, sparking an outcry from labour unions as well as opposition political parties. 
Government said it is consulting on the issue with a view to making changes to the law so that workers are protected. Zimbabwe
